awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Lithosphere-scale anisotropic imaging across the Eastern North American Margin's ocean-continent transition
awd_abstract_narration:
The cycle of continent formation and subsequent breakup to build oceans is an essential aspect of plate tectonics and is one of the fundamental processes that shape the planet. Yet, there are several details of continental rifting that continue to elude us. Rifted margins, such as that which comprises the entire east coast of the United States, represent the contact between continental crust and oceanic crust that is formed during, and after, the breakup (in this case, the Atlantic Ocean formed as Africa moved away). These margins retain a record of the processes that led up to, coincided with, and followed continental breakup. This project will utilize existing onshore and offshore seismic data to study in detail the deformation that produced the modern day eastern U.S. The results will aid in assessing contemporary hazard and risks along the margin. This project supports the training of a graduate student at the University of California at Santa Barbara and at least one undergraduate student at the University of Arizona. It also supports outreach activities to several high schools in North Carolina that hosted seismic instruments that recorded earthquake data used in the analyses.   


This project aims to shed light on two fundamental scientific questions related to the structure, evolution, and on-going dynamics associated with the eastern North American passive rift margin (ENAM): 1) What is the structure of the lithosphere from top to bottom across the ocean-continent transition and how was it shaped by rifting processes? 2) What is the history of deformation both within and seaward of the passive margin, and how is present-day mantle flow controlled by the margin's structure? Depth-constrained 3-D anisotropic velocity models will be produced of the ENAM from crust to below the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB). By employing different imaging techniques in sequence, we will create a suite of complementary models: a) 3-D isotropic shear velocity model from inversion of ambient noise and earthquake-generated surface waves; b) 1-D high-resolution velocity profiles using dispersion curves inverted jointly with S-p and P-s receiver functions sensitive to crust and mantle discontinuities; c) 3-D finite-frequency body-wave azimuthal anisotropy tomography using the surface wave tomography as a starting model. These models will be jointly interpreted to refine estimates of crustal thickness and LAB character across the margin in the context of geodynamical rifting models, as well as to understand deformational flow during rifting and margin maturation to the present day.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last two billion years, the North American continent has been built through a series of collisions between continental plates that have accumulated material and caused plate-scale deformation of the eastern side of the continent. The most recent of these – part of the assembly of the global supercontinent Pangea – helped build the Appalachian mountains. 200 million years ago, when Pangea fell apart, the eastern North American margin (the continent-ocean transition) developed, as North America and Eurasia/N. Africa stretched apart to the point of breaking, eventually yielding the Atlantic Ocean. Imaging of this relatively pristine extended (passive) margin offers insights into the processes of continental breakup.  Since rifting, North America’s eastern margin has mostly been tectonically boring, and was previously assumed to be inert. However, certain aspects of this margin have challenged this notion: relatively recent (50 Ma) volcanism, unexplained mantle thermal anomalies, modest intraplate seismicity. These factors, together with breakthroughs in tectonic plate-scale imaging and a wealth of community-generated datasets here, make eastern North America a fascinating focus for study. 

Intellectual merit:

We applied several novel methods to markedly improve images of this margin from the surface to beneath the plates:

1) We conducted three dimensional imaging of the margin that simultaneously captured, for the first time, both shear velocity (the speed of shear-wave propagation) and seismic “anisotropy” (the directional dependence of wavespeed). The former tells us about plates’ thermal structure, while the latter results from rock fabrics that result from shear through time, constraining plates’ history of deformation. 

2) We separately produced a 3-D shear velocity model of the continental plate from the margin to the interior (~88˚W) that captures the deep structure and even underside of the plate in unprecedented detail. This involved a cutting-edge approach to simultaneously incorporate multiple published (and some new) data sets of various data type, using a Bayesian statistical framework, together with methodological breakthroughs for efficient computation. Notably, we include (for the first time ever) information from scattered waves that have particular sensitivity to sharp gradients in seismic properties.

3) We detected and measured a specific type of seismic wave: the “quasi-Love wave” which is produced when a Love-type wave converts into a Rayleigh-type wave at a gradient in anisotropy. These detections allow us to project back along the incoming waves’ path to discover the locus of these anisotropic gradients. For the first time, we combined measurements of this sort at different frequencies, sensitive to different depths.

Some highlights of our results include:

  1. We imaged stretching fabrics in the plate at the margin leftover from its extension
  2. We found layered fabrics that show how the mantle flows underneath the plate
  3. We detected (as have others) a hole (or divot) in the plate associated with the location of the 50 Ma volcanoes. We hypothesize that this feature is maintained through ongoing dynamic processes associated with the steep gradients of the base of the plate.
  4. Our new 3-D model depicts, for the first time, the topography of the underside of the eastern North American plate, as well as its internal structure. The plate can be subdivided into distinct regions east of the Appalachians, between the Appalachians and an ancient geologic boundary, (the Grenville front) and then west of that boundary. 
  5. We see the effects of Pangean breakup still recorded in the plate margin: thin and hot lithosphere
  6. Under the Appalachians, we find thick crust and thin(ner) plate, explaining why these mountains have kept their elevation
  7. At the Grenville front, we see stacking of two plates, a leftover structure from the continent’s formation.
  8. We find three zones of thin plate and active upwelling associated with an abrupt step in plate thickness. Convective flow driven by this step drives present day active dynamics at what turns out to be a boundary that is far from inert.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project trained a graduate student at UCSB, who is poised to enter the geoscience workforce (directly led to government and industry internships).  Findings from this research have been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate classes at UCSB. Researchers from across the geoscience community have benefited from methodological and imaging improvements that alter how many fields conceive of the eastern North American plate.
